body.p: This document presents the documentation examples and guidelines of the Makumba website with Apache Forrest.

section.title: General document structure
section.p: The general document structure of a Forrest document is like this:
section.source:
Page title

Some introduction text, if necessary.

Section title

Section content

Subsection title

Subsection content
section.p: It is possible to give id's to sections, in order to refer to them via anchor links (myPage.html#mySection).
Forrest will automatically generate a table of contents for the page

section.title: Text styles
section.p: Text can be strong or emphasized:

Normal paragraphs
section.p: Normal paragraphs are easy to do:

Quoted text
section.note: We may add some more paragraph classes later on if needed.

section.title: Notes
section.p: It's possible to make notes easily:
Notes can have labels:
section.source: <note label="Custom label">This is a note with a label.</note>
section.note: This is a note with a label.

section.title: Warnings
section.p: It's possible to make warnings easily:
Warnings can have labels:
section.source: <warning label="Custom label">This is a warning with a label.</warning>
section.warning: This is a warning with a label.

section.title: Fixme's
section.p: It's possible to make FIXME elements. Those should be used in order to add FIXME's in the documentation, if needed:
FIXME's must have an author attribute.

section.title: Inlined HTML
section.p: If needed, it is possible to add inlined HTML to a page, e.g. to show examples of what some code renders. Inlined HTML should NOT be used to do the normal formatting, in that case, Forrest should be extended.

section.note: This is NOT a standard behaviour of Forrest. In order to work correctly, the content of the <ihtml> tag must be surrounded with CDATA. (this does not show correctly in the source above, since it would not rendred correctly otherwise)

section.title: Source code
section.p: Source code can be included using the <code> and the <source> tags:

section.title: <code> tag
section.source: <code>small code snippet, in the paragraph text</code

p.code: small code snippet, in the paragraph text

section.p: The <code> tag is part of a paragraph and should be used for small code snippets.
will generate:
The <source> tag is not part of a paragrah, and should be used to show larger examples of source code.
section.note: As for the <ihtml> tag, the content of the source tag should be surrounded by CDATA (this does not show correctly in the source above, since it would not rendred correctly otherwise) . It is not compulsory but a very good practice in order to keep indentation when formatting the XML document with some automatic formatting tool.

section.title: Links
section.p: It is possible to link to other pages:
or to specific sections, provided they have an id attribute:
If external links are used frequently, it is possible to add them to site.xml and use the ext: link:
In much the same way, the nodes in site.xml can be referred to using the site: link:
Note that those links use XPATH to determine to which node to link to.
